Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Communication Frameworks in Palliative Surgical Scenarios

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to view two videos depicting a physician-patient encounter using either the BC/WC or R/B framework.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to view two videos depicting a physician-patient encounter using either the BC/WC or R/B framework.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine if patients with advanced cancer prefer the best case/worst case (BC/WC) communication framework over the traditional risk/benefit (R/B) framework in palliative surgical scenarios.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the patients' preferred communication framework.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and outcome assessors were blinded to the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Conducted from November 2020 to May 2021, this double-blinded, video vignette-based randomised controlled trial involved 66 patients with advanced cancer.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 66 randomised, 58 completed the study

Result_Outcome.evidence: 22 patients (37.9%, 95%CI:25.4%−50.4%) preferred the BC/WC framework, 21 (36.2%, 95%CI:23.8%−48.6%) preferred the R/B framework, and 15 (25.9%, 95%CI:14.6%−37.2%) had no preference.
